channel.title: Perl Weekly newsletter
channel.description: A free, once a week e-mail round-up of hand-picked news and articles about Perl.

item.title: Thought-Leader Wanted. Chief Software Architect role in Malaysia
item.description: As Chief Software Architect for an international company providing online trading services, you’ll work closely with the Chief Technology Officer. With a strong understanding of the full stack of software development and cloud technologies, you’ll mentor engineering teams and provide guidance in solving technical issues.

item.title: Good (Perl) Humans Wanted. Remote Perl role in USA
item.description: Working with first responders, educators, manufacturers, and engineers, our client is the leading provider of award-winning intelligent SaaS solutions. They’re looking for a Perl developer with Catalyst and DBlx::Class and a solid base of experience,

item.title: NLP is all right by me! Perl, Python, NLP role in Amsterdam
item.description: A global leader in machine intelligence matching job seekers with their perfect career: our client’s goal is human level parsing. They’re on the hunt for an NLP Engineer whose passion for NLP is matched only by their interest in Machine Intelligence and their ability to drive quality improvements, measurement standards, and error analysis processes for the NLP framework.

item.title: A Perl Role Down Under? Bullseye! Perl role in Australia
item.description: This wonder-from-down-under company provides end-to-end data collection and management services and they’re looking for a Perl developer to join their team. To rack up the points, you’ll have experience with REST, Dancer2, Catalyst, Moo, DBlx::Class, MySQL, Postgres, and docker. AngularJS or Vue will bring you into bullseye range, so shout it out if this sounds like you.

item.title: Perl to Node Cross-training? Yes Please! UK Remote Perl Role
item.description: We’re looking for junior and mid-level Perl developers interested in cross-training Perl to Node. This role is remote-friendly for those located within the UK. Perl may be your core competency, but if you’re invested in cross-training to Node, you may be the full package that this client wants on their team.

item.title: NICEPERL's lists
item.description:
Great CPAN modules released last week;
MetaCPAN weekly report;
StackOverflow Perl report.

item.title: The Weekly Challenge 154: Missing Padovan
item.description: The best hack to find the missing. Prepare the possible list and delete item from the input list to find the missing. No gimmicks. Keep it up great work.

item.title: Perming Perl plus Padovan primes
item.description: Short and precise blog to cover up the details of working. Thanks for sharing.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 154
item.description: Luis is known for his one-liner in Perl using CPAN module. The end result is short and compact. Well done.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 154: lazyness and recursion
item.description: Luca showing off one-liner in Raku. Amazing power of Raku. Keep it up great work.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 154: Missing Permutations and Padovan Primes
item.description: Lots of Raku magic in this week blog as usual. If you are new to Raku then this is the good start for you. Keep it up great work.

item.title: The Weekly Challenge #154 - do and redo there is no try!
item.description: James is not afraid of using bit operator. It makes code compact, very clever. Thanks for sharing the knowledge.

item.title: PWC154 - Padovan Prime
item.description: I liked the order of solution, Perl first then Raku. It gives better comparison how Raku behaves. Thank you for your effort.

item.title: PWC154 - Missing Permutation
item.description: The best part is home grown solution for permutation in Perl. Cool attempt. Keep it up great work.

item.title: A Quick One While I Do Other Things: Weekly Challenge #154
item.description: Dave style of blogging is also very interesting and catchy. I liked how Dave plays with the week number. Thanks for sharing.

item.title: Padovans Dog
item.description: Colin always surpised us with amazing stuff in his blog. You really don't want to miss it. Incredible, keep it up great work.

item.title: Who Took My Cheese?
item.description: The best of the blog, is the approach to solve the task. It is like solving the puzzle by putting all the pieces one by one. Masterpiece.

item.title: TWC Episode 154 - Padawan Missing
item.description: Thanks Bruce for the bonus this week. The quality blog content has Perl, Raku and Python. Keep it up great work.

item.title: Padovan is Missing with Raku and Perl
item.description: Arne always shares multiple solutions of each task, showing different aspects. I liked the Perl and Raku comparison most. Thanks for sharing your knowledge with us.

item.title: Padovan Prime Directive: Find the Missing Permutations
item.description: Loved the use of handy CPAN modules like Algorithm::Loops and Math::Primality. Thanks for sharing new ideas.

item.title: Perl Review - Perl Weekly Challenge - 150
item.description: Perl Solutions Review by Colin Crain.

item.title: RECAP - The Weekly Challenge - 154
item.description: Enjoy a quick recap of last week's contributions by Team PWC dealing with the "Missing Permutation" and "Padovan Prime" tasks in Perl and Raku. You will find plenty of solutions to keep you busy.

item.title: The Weekly Challenge - 155
item.description: Welcome to a new week with a couple of fun tasks "Fortunate Numbers" and "Pisano Period". If you are new to the weekly challenge then why not join us and have fun every week. For more information, please read the FAQ.

item.title: WebService::SmartRow
item.description: Quick and easy interface to connect and get data from SmartRow API.

item.title: App::Easer - tree auto-command
item.description: Introduction of tree sub-command to the automatically available ones.

item.title: Fail2ban2geo
item.description: Short demo of Fail2ban2geo tool.

item.title: GeoIP database from MaxMind
item.description: Cool use of IP::Geolocation::MMDB and free database by MaxMind to create magic.

item.title: Cloud Provider Performance Comparison - Perl & more
item.description: Interesting performance comparison and very detailed analysis. Highly recommended if you are looking for right cloud provider.

item.title: I start to write the book "Perl for Beginners to Mastering Perl in a week"
item.description: An honest attempt by Yuki to write Perl book. Please do spread the news.

item.title: #554 - Exceptions in Perl?
item.description:
Hi there

I borrowed the title from Curtis recently shared gist. I am sure everyone of us have dealt with exceptions in Perl. Being a CPAN fan, I found plenty of choices readily available. I am a big fan of Try::Tiny and has been my first choice always to deal with exceptions in Perl. I suggest you must check out the gist for more insights and suggestions shared by Curtis.

I would also like to share another gem by Curtis, i.e. Porting from Moose or Moo. It is a big help for anyone to move to Corinna from Moose or Moo. Most of my personal work shared on MetaCPAN used Moo. The document by Curtis would be handy when porting to Corinna once it is part of core Perl. I am eagerly waiting for it to happen.

Finally, this is my 99th edition of the weekly newsletter. In two weeks time, I would be presenting the 100th edition. I joined the team of editors in May 2018, thanks to the chief editor, Gabor Szabo, for all the support and guidance.

Enjoy rest of the newsletter and pray for the world peace.
item.dc:subject: list of tags?
